Coney Island, baby! The romance of mid-century New York – in pictures Coney Island, baby! The romance of mid-century New York – in pictures View more sharing options Share on Messenger Close 
With their carefree joy tempered with moments of poignancy, Harold Feinstein’s shots of ordinary New Yorkers helped kickstart the street photography boom Wednesday 1 February 2017 07.00 GMT Coke Sign on the Boardwalk, 1949 Harold Feinstein captured a city full of verve and confidence in his shots of mid-20th century New York. An exhibition of his works is at Galerie Thierry Bigaignon, Paris , 3 February to 30 April, part of the French capital’s month of photography 2017 Photograph: All photographs: Harold Feinstein Boy With Chalk Numbers, 1955 Feinstein was born in 1931 in Coney Island, Brooklyn, to immigrant parents from Austria and Ukraine. He began taking photographs at the age of 15 Two Men and a Boy Contemplate, 1950 The photographer Edward Steichen was an early supporter of Feinstein’s work, buying shots for the Museum of Modern Art Coney Island Teenagers, 1949 Feinstein immersed himself in the vibrancy of New York, photographing its people and its streets 125th Street from Elevated Train, 1950 He was a jazz fan, capturing the scene around the Jazz Loft alongside W Eugene Smith , and designing record covers for Blue Note Sightseeing Bus NYC, 1956 Feinstein is best known for his New York work – particularly street shots from his native Coney Island – but he also produced work during the Korean war, capturing the naivety of new conscripts Bidding Farewell, 1952 Here, a couple kisses goodbye on the train platform at Camp Kilmer, New Jersey, as soldiers depart for Korea Broken Christ With Children, Coney Island, 1950 Feinstein later started experimenting with colour – and later still used a scanner to photograph flowers in hyper-real digital detail Blanket Toss, 1955 ‘Coney Island was my Treasure Island. Mostly, I worked so quickly I didn’t see the details of a photograph until it was printed,’ he told the Guardian’s Jenny Stevens in 2014 . ‘There were so many things to shoot, the question was not how to take a good picture, but how not to miss one. You had Italians, Puerto Ricans, people from all over the world, and you didn’t have to pay to go there – it was truly a people’s place’ Boy With Sunglasses, 1950 ‘I loved riding the Cyclone rollercoaster. I’d get a seat right at the front. Then I’d stand up while going down the steepest drop, turn round, and shoot whoever was behind me screaming’ Kids Ride the Whip, 1950 ‘The advice I give my students is this: when your jaw drops, click the shutter. My jaw dropped all the time on Coney Island’ Sharing a Public Bench, 1949 Feinstein died in 2015; the New York Times declared he was ‘one of the most accomplished recorders of the American experience’ in his obituary Topics
